div.head: Plates
div.p:
svasti. śrīmatāṁ sakala-bhu
vana-saṁstūyamāna-mānavya-sagotrāṇāṁ hārīti-putrāṇāṁ kauśikī-vara-prasāda
-labdha-rājyānāṁ mātr̥-gaṇa-paripālitānāṁ svāmi-mahāsena-pādānu
dhyātānāṁ bhagavan-nārāyaṇa-prasāda-samāsādita-vara-varāha-lāñcha
nekṣaṇa-kṣaṇa-vaśīkr̥tārāti-maṇḍalānāṁ Aśvamedhāvabhr̥tha-snāna-pavitrīkr̥
ta-vapuṣāṁ cāḷukyānāṁ kulam alaṁkārkariṣṇos satyāśraya-vallabhendrasya bhrātā||

tad-ātmajo jayasiṁhas trayastriṁśaT| tad-anujendrarāja-nandano vi
ṣṇuvarddhano nava| tat-sūnur mmaṅgi-yuvarājaḥ pañcaviṁśati| tat-putro jayasiṁhas tra
yodaśa| tad-avarajaḥ kokiliḥ ṣaṇ māsāN| tasya jyeṣṭho bhrātā viṣṇuvardhanas tam uccāṭya sapta
triṁśaT| tat-putro vijayāditya-bhaṭṭārako ’ṣṭādaśa| tat-suto viṣṇuvardhanaḥ ṣaṭtri
ṁśaT|

lg.l:
kr̥tvā prottuṅgam aṣṭottara-śatam abhunag vī
ra-dhīro ’ṣṭa-yuktāś
tuṅgādreḥ śr̥ṅgam urvyām aśanir iva mudāpātayat kannarāṅkaṁ

niśśa
ṁkaṁ śaṁkilena pradhthita-janapadād durggamān nirggamayya

drāg dāvaṁ yaḥ praveśyaḥ prabhur abhaya
-manāṁḥ pratyapād baddhagāṅkaṁ|

mā
tāvat triṁśad abdān bhuvam abhunag asau cāru-cālukya-bhīmaḥ||

svarṇṇārū
ḍha-tulo ’tra bāḍham atulo dhātrī-tale kṣatriyair

mmitrābhaḥ parirakṣati sma vijayāditya
s samārddhaṁ dharāM|

varṣāṇi sapta samapād bhuvam ammarā
jaḥ|

vajrīvorjji
ta-nākam amma-nr̥pater bhrātā kanīyān bhuvaṁ

bhīmo bhīma-parākramas samabhunak saṁvatsarān dvā
daśa||
tat-sūnur ammarājo pi dharma-paraḥ pañcaviṁśatiṁ ca samāḥ

app.note: The invocatory stanza was probably a gīti, possibly a different member of the āryā family. I cannot reconstruct a meaningful and metrical reading. MN shows divyojva and ṭā in round parentheses, which elsewhere he uses for emendation. But in the present case I see no reason why he would have wanted to emend the preceding syllables to these strings; also, the number of akṣaras in this line would be very small compared to adjacent lines if the parenthetical text were not present on the plate. Scribal errors may well be present in addition to misreading and misprinting. The composer's intent probably included the words jaṭā and karāñjali, and yatra or an equivalent is sorely missing. See the translation for my interpretation.
Since MN prints a double v after this word, but does not supply r, I assume r is present in the original.
I emend on the basis of the parallel stanza in the Kalucuṁbaṟṟu grant of Amma II.
Since MN does not emend, I assume the original text has the correct dh.
Again, I merely assume that the original is correct.
Here and in lines 12 and 13 below, MN of course prints °triṁśat without explicit indication that a final consonant is present. The actual reading is perhaps °triṁśata, intended for °triṁśataṁ.

I overrule MN on the basis of the parallels in the Tāṇḍikoṇḍa grant of Amma II and the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman. Given the length of the line, the missing sequence is probably omitted in the original, not a typo in MN's edition.
The locus reads -dhīr aṣṭa- in the Tāṇḍikoṇḍa grant of Amma II and -dhīroṣṭa- in the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman. The latter is perhaps more likely here.
I overrule MN on the basis of the parallels in the Nāgiyapūṇḍi grant of Amma II and the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman.

Parallels of this stanza are found in the Nāgiyapūṇḍi grant of Amma II and the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman. The former very clearly reads durggaman here, while the latter is unclear, but was read as durggamān by its editor.

Of the two parallels, Amma's grant clearly reads dāvaṁ here (misread or misprinted by its original editor as dhāvaṁ, perhaps under the influence of the present grant's published edition), while Śaktivarman's plates are wholly illegible at this locus (but their original editor supplies dhāvaṁ). In my opinion dāvaṁ is the only sensible choice, but this does not exclude the possibility that MN's reading is correct here, in which case the present text needs emendation.
The word is baddegāṁkaṁ in both parallels, and that is the correct form of the name. I assume that the plates are erroneous here, but this may also be a typo in MN's edition.

MN does not emend this word and may have read or printed it incorrectly. The original editor of the Nāgiyapūṇḍi grant of Amma II also prints bhūpate, probably on the basis of the present grant, though the reading there is clearly bhūpati (with or without r).
Both known parallels read vaṭu here, which is superior. MN may have misread the plate.
Both known parallels read māteva here. As mātāvat is morphologically incorrect, I tend to believe MN misread the plate here.
I am tempted to emend to -balo, but the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman have the same reading.
The s may be a typo in MN, but since the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman read the same, I assume it is an original mistake.

The Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman are unclear here and their text is more corrupt, but given MN's reading for this locus and the facsimile of the parallel, this seems to be the most likely reading. See the translation for my tentative interpretation.
The parallel is quite clear here.

I understand MN's edition to mean that he emends an inscribed ko to tā. The emendation is vindicated by the parallel stanza in the Pāṁbaṟṟu grant of Amma II and the Andhra Sahitya Parishad plates of Śaktivarman.
I emend on the basis of parallels in several other grants.

I emend with some hesitation. MN may have perceived this as a prose passage, but its prosody is too close to a gaṇacchandas structure to be accidental. The visarga in samāḥ also suggests a hemistich boundary. Removing this pi, coupled with some improvements of MN's reading (confirmed by the facsimile), results in a perfect specimen of the rare metre lalitā. Perhaps pi was added because the drafter of the grant too, while adopting a pre-existing text, believed this to be prose and thus permissive of small changes.

For this locus, MN shows dhanyaḥ(vān). He may have intended to emend to satyavān yaḥ, or to indicate the latter as a possible alternative reading. The vowel of dh does seem to be ā, but by my perception a relative pronoun would be out of the syntax here, so I prefer to read dhanyaḥ.
It seems from MN's discussion that he interpreted suno as a nominative. See my commentary on this stanza.

I agree with MN (who prints all of this word as clear) that this is the most likely reading, though out of context and from the estampage, I would read the unclear character as ca. There is plenty of noise in the last three characters, and correction may have happened here, perhaps from or to mahībhujaś ca or mahībhujaḥ sa.

The unclear first character of this word looks neither like na, nor like Ā. Although Indoskript shows an Ā from a 9th-century Gaṅga grant that looks somewhat similar, it is a form I have never seen in any Eastern Cālukya plate, and that Ā is probably malformed, in comparison to the A of the same grant. Pending an autopsy of the original, I believe that this character was meant to be na, perhaps malformed or corrected from something else. Conceivably, it might be ṇa intended for na. See also my commentary on this stanza.

The text works with a nominative (in which case this word describes Dānārṇava), but because of proximity and the word-play in kalā/kali, I prefer to understand this word as describing Kali Viṣṇuvardhana in spite of the slightly more awkward syntax involved.
The fact that MN prints ḷ here, where l is clear in the rubbing, casts doubt on his ḷ in lines 7 and 11, for which no facsimile is available.
Only the left edge of y is visible in the estampage. Depending on the ending of the word urjapā (see note below), the stanza would also be intelligible and mean the same with sutāyāṁ.

The first vowel of this name may perhaps be ū, as the name appears in secondary literature, but in the rubbing it seems to be u. The ending may be yāḥ instead of yāM (see also the note on sutāyāṁ above), but does not seem to be simply yāṁ.
This is clearly the word intended, but the actually inscribed word may be dhr̥ḍha or ḍhr̥ḍha.

Although there is plenty of noise in the estampage here, MN's reading seems quite certain except for kṣamā, which is definitely kṣama, and sri, probably a typo for śri, which is a plausible but far from certain reading of the the last character in line 39, partly obscured by the rim of the plate. I have only awkward ideas for interpreting this sequence. I think kṣama-m is probably non-standard sandhi for kṣama (epenthetic m inserted to avoid hiatus); scribal error for kṣama Āśrito is also a possibility. The string āśritovat was perhaps intended to be āśritoddhr̥t, one who uplifts.

The m in MN's reading was presumably meant to be ṁ; it is shown in round parentheses, which may mean that it is supplied rather than unclear. His ihor must have been intended for ihoru. As indicated in my markup, much of the last line is unclear, and this applies in particular to any character components below the baseline. Nonetheless, I am quite sure that MN's sya must be read as sva, because the end of a subscript y would ascend next to the body. Reading h in deham ihoru is possible (compare the ha in br̥had, line 38) assuming that the tail of ha is largely obliterated, but because of the narrowness of both of the implicated characters, I think the text is more likely to be devam ivoru. I am far from certain of my reading and of my enedation, much less of my understanding of the text. Nonetheless, if an epenthetic m is assumed (as in the first hemistich, see the note above), then dharmmaḥ svayaṁ deva-m ivoru-kīrttir (for deva Ivoru-) is intelligible and fits the context.

This is a minor point, but the subscript v is faintly visible under the primary one, and the stem of the subscript v is clear, rising to head height next to the body of the principal one. This in turn confirms that the preceding word ends in r, even though a repha is not distinct here.
The heavy noise below ja implies a subscript consonant, but even though bhū-jana is a little awkward, any alternative reading (e.g. ’bhūj jana) would be inappropriate in the context.

In the character I read as lo, a vowel marker on the right-hand (the tail of l) is indeed clear, but a second vowel stroke may well be attached to the bottom left of the body. The final visarga is almost distinct.

div.p: Reported in 10A/1937-387 with discussion at 81-8212. Edited from the original by Manda Narasimham (), with partial estampages (showing plates 3v to 5v, but not the earlier plates and the seal) and a summary of the contents. The present edition by Dániel Balogh is based on a collation of Narasimham's edition with his facsimiles where available.Where no estampage is available, I follow Narasimham unless otheriwse noted and do not indicate the position of binding holes. Minor typographic mistakes in Narasimham's edition (which are numerous) are ignored in the apparatus here.
